choices.text: Use of Abate in stagnant water
Introduction of larvivorous fish in ponds

questions.text: Which of the following is not an anti-larval mosquito control measure?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Indoor residual spraying targets adult mosquitoes, not larvae.

Anti-Larval Measures:

  • Environmental Control (Source Reduction):
    • Eliminate breeding sites via:
      • Filling, drainage, levelling.
      • Water management (e.g., intermittent irrigation).
      • Changing the salinity of water.
    • Species-specific actions:
      • Culex: Remove sewage pools, ditches.
      • Aedes: Eliminate containers (tins, pots, shells).
      • Anopheles: Fill stagnant water bodies.
      • Mansonia: Remove aquatic plants/herbicide use.
    • Permanent effect if maintained.
  • Chemical Control:
    • Mineral Oils: (Option A)
      • Forms a film on water; suffocates larvae/pupae.
      • Applied weekly; 40-90 L/ha.
      • Not suitable for drinking water, kills fish.
    • Paris Green:
      • Stomach poison; kills surface-feeding larvae (Anopheles).
      • Safe for fish/humans.
      • 2% dust, 1 kg/ha.
    • Synthetic Insecticides: (Option B)
      • Fenthion, Chlorpyrifos, Abate (organophosphates).
      • Rapidly degrade in water.
      • Abate (1 ppm) is effective and low toxicity.
      • Avoid DDT, HCH due to resistance and pollution.
  • Biological Control: (Option D)
    • Larvivorous fish: Gambusia, Lebistes.
    • Used in ponds, cisterns, and oxidation pits.
    • Supplementary to other methods.

questions.text: The number of water-holding containers infected with Aedes larvae per 100 houses inspected is known as:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Breteau Index refers to the number of positive containers with Aedes immatures per 100 houses inspected.

Mosquito Surveillance:

  • Essential for effective mosquito control at points of entry.
  • Common indices used:
    • House Index (HI): % of houses infested with larvae or pupae. (Option B)
    • Container Index (CI): % of water-holding containers infested. (Option A)
    • Breteau Index (BI): Number of positive containers per 100 houses.
    • Pupal Index (PI): Number of pupae per 100 houses. (Option D)

Reference:

https://www.ihpoe.mohfw.gov.in/vector.php

questions.text: Per capita water requirement in urban areas for all domestic purposes is recommended at:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In urban areas, the per capita water requirement for all domestic purposes (including drinking, cooking, bathing, washing, etc.) is recommended to be 150-200 litres per person per day, as per public health standards.

Water Requirement:

  • Basic survival needs:
    • ~2 litres/person/day (just for drinking and survival).
  • Public health standard:
    • Adequate water supply is essential to reduce water-related diseases and improve the quality of life.
  • Urban areas:
    • 150-200 litres/person/day is considered adequate for all domestic purposes.
  • Rural India target:
    • 40 litres/person/day was set as the supply goal.

choices.text: Absence of a safe water source within 1.6 km
Water available only beyond 15 meters depth
Presence of excess salinity, iron, or fluorides

questions.text: Criteria for defining a 'Problem Village' include all except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Guinea worm infection is not part of the official criteria for defining a 'Problem Village.

Definition of a 'Problem Village':

A village is classified as a Problem Village if:

  1. No safe water source is available: (Option A & B)
    1. Within a distance of 6 km, OR
    2. At a depth of 15 meters.
  2. The available water source has: (Option C)
    1. Excess salinity
    2. High iron content
    3. High fluoride levels
    4. Other toxic elements
  3. The water source is at risk of cholera contamination.

choices.text: Coagulation → Sedimentation → Rapid mixing → Filtration → Flocculation
Coagulation → Rapid mixing → Flocculation → Sedimentation → Filtration
Rapid mixing → Coagulation → Sedimentation → Filtration → Flocculation
Flocculation → Coagulation → Rapid mixing → Sedimentation → Filtration

questions.text: What is the correct sequence of steps in the purification of water using rapid sand filters?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The correct order of steps used in rapid sand filtration is Coagulation → Rapid mixing → Flocculation → Sedimentation → Filtration.

Rapid Sand Filters:

  • Widely used in industrialised countries
  • Types:
    • Gravity type (e.g., Paterson's filter)
    • Pressure type (e.g., Candy's filter)
  • Purification Steps:
    1. Coagulation:
      • Add coagulant (e.g., alum): 5 - 40 mg/L
      • Dose depends on turbidity, colour, temp, pH
    2. Rapid Mixing:
      • Vigorous mixing in the chamber for uniform alum distribution
    3. Flocculation:
      • Gentle stirring in flocculation chamber (~30 mins) with paddles (2 - 4 rpm)
      • Forms thick, white flocculant (aluminium hydroxide)
    4. Sedimentation:
      • Settling for 2 - 6 hours
      • Removes ≥95% floc; sludge removed periodically
    5. Filtration:
      • Clarified water passed through rapid sand filters

choices.text: To measure the turbidity of incoming water
To measure bed resistance or loss of head
To control the speed of paddle rotation in flocculation

questions.text: What is the primary purpose of a Venturi meter in a rapid sand filter system?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Venturi Meter:

  • Used to measure bed resistance or "loss of head" in filters
  • Helps maintain a steady filtration rate
  • When resistance increases, the operator opens the regulating valve
  • If the loss of head > 1.3 meters, filter operation becomes uneconomical

Explanation of other options:

To measure turbidity of incoming water (Option A): Turbidity is measured using a turbidimeter or nephelometer, not a Venturi meter. Venturi meters measure flow-related pressure changes, not turbidity.

To regulate the chemical dose (Option B): Chemical dosing (e.g., alum in coagulation) is done using dosing pumps or chemical feeders, not a Venturi meter.

To control the speed of paddle rotation in flocculation (Option D): Paddle speed is controlled by motors and gear systems, not by a Venturi meter. The Venturi meter is unrelated to the flocculation unit.

questions.text: The disinfecting action of chlorine in water is mainly due to which of the following?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Hypochlorous acid is the most effective disinfecting form of chlorine in water, especially at a pH of around 7.

Action of Chlorine:

  • Chlorine + Water → Forms hydrochloric acid (HCl) and hypochlorous acid (HOCl)
    • Reaction:
      • Cl2 + H2O → HCl + HOCl
      • HOCl → H+ + OCl
  • Hydrochloric acid is neutralised by water's alkalinity
  • Disinfection action is mainly due to:
    • Hypochlorous acid (HOCl): Primary and most effective disinfectant
    • Hypochlorite ion (OCl): Less effective (HOCl is 70-80× more effective)
  • Chlorine is most effective at pH ~7 (HOCl predominates)
  • At pH >8.5, chlorine becomes unreliable:
    • ~90% of HOCl is converted to less effective OCl
  • Most natural waters have a pH of 6-7.5, making chlorine generally effective

Explanation of other options:

Hydrochloric acid (Option A): Formed when chlorine reacts with water but is neutralised by alkalinity; does not contribute to disinfection.

Hypochlorite ions (Option C): Have some disinfecting action, but are much less effective than hypochlorous acid; formed at higher pH levels.

Chloride ions (Option D): Not involved in the disinfection process of water.

questions.text: In Horrock's test, if the 4th white cup is the first to show a blue colour, how much bleaching powder is required to disinfect 455 litres of water?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Each drop corresponds to 2 g of bleaching powder. If the 4th cup shows blue first, then 4 drops (i.e., 4 × 2 g = 8 g) are needed to disinfect 455 litres of water.

Horrock's Apparatus:

  • Purpose: Determines the bleaching powder dose for water disinfection.
  • Contents:
    • 6 white cups, 1 black cup (marked), 2 metal spoons (2 g each), 7 glass rods, 1 pipette, 2 droppers, starch-iodide indicator, instruction manual.
  • Procedure:
    • Prepare stock solution: 2 g bleaching powder in a black cup → make a paste → dilute to the mark → stir → settle.
    • Fill 6 white cups with test water.
    • Add 1-6 drops of stock solution (1st to 6th cup).
    • Stir each with a separate rod.
    • Wait 30 minutes.
    • Add 3 drops of indicator to each cup → stir.
    • First blue cup = required dose.
      • e.g., 3rd cup blue → 6 g bleaching powder needed for 455 L water.

choices.text: Chlorination is effective even in turbid water
Chlorine demand includes free residual chlorine
Minimum 0.5 mg/L of free residual chlorine should be present after 1 hour
Break-point is reached before the chlorine demand is fulfilled

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the chlorination of water?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Free residual chlorine of at least 0.5 mg/L for 1 hour ensures disinfection and safety against post-treatment contamination.

Principles of Chlorination:

  • Clear Water:
    • Must be clear and free from turbidity for effective chlorination. (Option A)
    • Turbidity impedes efficient chlorination.
  • Chlorine Demand:
    • Chlorine demand = Chlorine added - Residual chlorine after 60 minutes at a given temperature and pH. (Option B)
    • Represents the amount of chlorine consumed to destroy microbes, oxidise impurities and neutralise amonical substances.
  • Break-Point:
    • A breakpoint is when chlorine demand is fully met. (Option D)
    • Beyond this, free chlorine (HOCl and OCl-)
  • Contact Time:
    • A minimum contact period of one hour is essential.
    • Ensures the destruction of bacteria and viruses.
    • Spores, protozoal cysts, and helminthic ova are resistant and require higher doses.
  • Free Residual Chlorine:
    • Minimum recommended level:5 mg/L for at least 1 hour. (Option C)
    • Provides a safety margin against recontamination during storage/distribution.
  • Correct Chlorine Dose:
    • Chlorine dose = Chlorine demand + 0.5 mg/L (free residual chlorine)

questions.text: Which of the following tests is commonly used to estimate free and combined chlorine in water?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The ortho-toluidine test is a colourimetric method used to estimate both free and combined chlorine in water samples.

Orthotolidine (OT) Test:

  • Purpose:
    • Measures both free and combined chlorine in water quickly and accurately.
  • Reagent Composition:
    • Orthotolidine (analytical grade) dissolved in 10% hydrochloric acid.
  • Principle:
    • Turns yellow when added to chlorinated water.
    • The intensity of yellow varies with chlorine concentration.
    • Reacts instantly with free chlorine, slowly with combined chlorine.
  • Procedure:
    • Add 1 ml of reagent to 1 ml of water sample.
    • Compare the yellow colour with the standard colour discs.
    • Read within 10 seconds to estimate free chlorine.
    • Colour after 15-20 minutes reflects total (free + combined) chlorine.

Explanation of other options:

Nitrates in water (Option A): Estimated using the brucine method or phenoldisulfonic acid method, not ortho-toluidine.

Nitrites in water (Option B): Detected by the Griess-Ilosvay method, not by ortho-toluidine.

Ammonia content in water (Option D): Assessed by Nessler's reagent test, not ortho-toluidine.

choices.text: It helps in the destruction of chloramines
It ensures the presence of free residual chlorine after combined chlorine is eliminated
It is an uncontrolled form of superchlorination
It requires increasing the chlorine dose until residual chlorine begins to rise again

questions.text: All the following statements are true about breakpoint chlorination, except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Break-point chlorination is a controlled process, not uncontrolled, and is used to eliminate combined chlorine effectively.

Break-Point Chlorination:

  • Initial Reaction:
    • Chlorine + ammonia → chloramines (less effective disinfectants than free chlorine).
  • Increasing Chlorine Dose:
    • Leads to the destruction of chloramines, reducing residual chlorine levels. (Option A)
  • Zero Residual Point:
    • At one stage, no residual chlorine remains as all chloramines are destroyed.
  • Break-Point:
    • Further chlorine addition causes free residual chlorine to reappear. (Option B & D)
    • The point where all combined chlorine is destroyed is called the break-point.
    • The corresponding chlorine dose is the break-point dosage.
  • Significance:
    • Achieves effective disinfection by ensuring only free chlorine
    • Considered a form of controlled superchlorination. (Option C)

choices.text: Carbonate hardness is mainly due to calcium and magnesium bicarbonates
Permanent hardness is caused by calcium and magnesium sulphates, chlorides, and nitrates
One milliequivalent per litre of hardness equals 100 mg of CaCO3
Water is considered very hard when hardness exceeds 6 mEq/L

questions.text: Which of the following statements about water hardness is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

1 mEq/L of hardness equals 50 mg CaCO3, not 100 mg.

Hardness of Water:

  • Hardness is defined as the ability of water to prevent soap from lathering.
  • Water is considered hard when large amounts of soap are needed to produce lather.
  • Causes of Hardness:
    • Main compounds responsible:
      • Calcium bicarbonate
      • Magnesium bicarbonate
      • Calcium sulphate
      • Magnesium sulphate
    • Other minor contributors:
      • Chlorides and nitrates of calcium and magnesium
      • Iron, manganese, and aluminium compounds
  • Types of Hardness:
    • Carbonate Hardness (Temporary hardness): (Option A)
      • Caused by calcium and magnesium bicarbonates.
    • Non-Carbonate Hardness (Permanent hardness): (Option B)
      • Caused by calcium and magnesium sulphates, chlorides, and nitrates.
  • Measurement:
    • Expressed in milliequivalents per litre (mEq/L).
    • 1 mEq/L of hardness-producing ion = 50 mg of CaCO3 per litre = 50 ppm. (Option C)
  • Classification of Water Hardness:

  • Drinking water should be moderately hard.
  • Water softening is recommended when hardness exceeds 3 mEq/L (150 mg/L as CaCO3).

questions.text: Which of the following sets of chemicals is correctly used in the Nalgonda technique for defluoridation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Nalgonda technique uses aluminium salts (e.g., alum) for fluoride removal, lime to form flocs, and bleaching powder for disinfection.

Nalgonda Technique:

  • Developed by NEERI (National Environmental Engineering Research Institute), Nagpur.
  • Steps Involved:
    1. Addition of aluminium salts (alum/aluminium chloride or both)
    2. Addition of lime (1/20th dose of aluminium salt)
    3. Addition of bleaching powder (3 mg/L)
    4. Rapid mixing
    5. Flocculation
    6. Sedimentation
    7. Filtration
    8. Disinfection
  • Chemical Roles:
    • Aluminium salts: Remove fluoride
    • Lime: Aids in dense floc formation for settling
      • Dose: 1/20th of the aluminium salt dose
    • Bleaching powder: For disinfection (3 mg/L)
    • Aluminium salt dose increases with higher fluoride and alkalinity of raw water
  • Advantages:
    • Usable at the domestic and community level
    • Cost-effective
    • Simple design, construction, operation, and maintenance
    • Low-tech, suitable at the point of use and source
    • Also removes turbidity, colour, odour, pesticides, and organic substances

Reference:

https://journals.lww.com/jhrr/fulltext/2014/01010/defluoridation_techniques__which_one_to_choose.1.aspx

questions.text: Biochemical Oxygen Demand (BOD) is a measure of which of the following in water?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

BOD indicates the amount of oxygen required by bacteria to break down organic matter in water over a specified period.

Biochemical Oxygen Demand (BOD):

  • BOD is the most important test done on sewage.
  • It is defined as the amount of oxygen absorbed by a sample of sewage during a specified period, generally:
    • 5 days
    • At a temperature of 20°C
  • This oxygen is used for the aerobic decomposition of organic matter by microorganisms.
  • Normal Range of BOD:
    • Natural waters: ~ 1 mg/L
    • Untreated domestic sewage: ~ 300 mg/L
  • Classification based on BOD:
    • Weak sewage: BOD ≈ 100 mg/L
    • Strong sewage: BOD ≥ 300 mg/L

questions.text:
True about sewage is/are:
A. Contains waste from houses, streets, and industries
B. Flow of sewage remains constant throughout the day
C. Dry weather flow is measured over 24 hours
D. Sewage is mostly composed of solid waste
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Sewage includes waste from homes, streets, and industries, and dry weather flow refers to the average sewage flow over 24 hours.

Sewage:

  • Sewage is wastewater from a community, containing:
    • Solid and liquid excreta
    • Waste from houses, street and yard washings, factories, and industries (Statement A)
  • It resembles dirty water with an unpleasant smell.
  • Factors Affecting Quantity of Sewage:
    • Habits of the people:
      • Greater water usage = More sewage generated
    • Time of day:
      • Sewage flow is not uniform throughout the day: (Statement B)
        • Morning: Peak flow (more water used)
        • Midday: Reduced flow
        • Evening: Slight increase again
    • Dry Weather Flow (DWF):
      • The average amount of sewage that flows in 24 hours through the sewerage system (Statement C)
    • Composition of Sewage:
      • Water content: ~9% (Statement D)
      • Solids: ~1%, which are:
        • Partly organic and inorganic
        • Partly suspended and dissolved

questions.text: Which parameter is most appropriate for measuring the organic load in wastewater when toxic substances may interfere with biological processes?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Chemical Oxygen Demand (COD):

  • COD measures the oxygen equivalent of the organic matter in a sample that is susceptible to oxidation by a strong chemical oxidiser.
  • Purpose of COD Test:
    • It is used to estimate the organic load in wastewater.
  • Advantages:
    • The COD test is instrumental when toxic substances are present in the waste, as biological methods like BOD may not be effective.
    • In such cases, COD may be the only practical method to assess organic pollution.

Explanation of other options:

Biological oxygen demand (Option A) may not give accurate results when toxic substances inhibit microbial activity.

Suspended solids (Option C) measures solid particles in water, not organic load or oxygen demand.

Total dissolved solids (Option D) measures all dissolved substances, but not specifically organic matter or oxygen demand.

questions.text:
Which of the following are correctly matched pairs of disease class and examples?
A. Water-borne - Cholera, Typhoid, Hepatitis A
B. Water-washed - Trachoma, Impetigo, Scabies
C. Water-based - Giardiasis, Cryptosporidiosis
D. Insect-vector - Malaria, Onchocerciasis, Leishmaniasis
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Reference:

https://www.researchgate.net/figure/Classification-of-water-related-diseases_tbl1_351665808

choices.text: Estimate the most probable number of coliform organisms in 100 ml of water
Detect the presence of faecal streptococci in a sample of water
Detect the presence of Clostridium perfringens in a sample of water
Determine the total colony count of bacteria in a water sample

questions.text: The Multiple Tube Method for MPN is used to:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The MPN (most probable number) method is specifically designed to estimate the number of coliforms in 100 ml of water using statistical probability.

Multiple Tube Method:

  • Purpose: Used to estimate the Most Probable Number (MPN) of coliform organisms in 100 ml of water.
  • Procedure:
    • Measured quantities of the water sample (e.g., 1 ml, 1.0 ml, 10 ml, 50 ml) are inoculated into tubes containing MacConkey's Lactose Bile Salt Broth.
    • Bromocresol purple is used as the pH indicator.
    • Tubes are incubated for 48 hours.
    • Acid and gas production are observed in the tubes.
  • Interpretation:
    • The number of positive tubes is used to estimate the MPN of coliforms per 100 ml, using statistical tables.
    • The result is termed the "presumptive coliform count".
    • Presumption: Each tube showing fermentation contains coliform organisms.
    • Limitation: The reaction may occasionally be due to other organisms or a combination of organisms.

Explanation of other options:

Detect the presence of faecal streptococci in a sample of water (Option B): This requires selective media and culture techniques specifically for faecal streptococci, such as Enterococcus agar. The MPN multiple tube method is not used for detecting these organisms.

Detect the presence of Clostridium perfringens in a sample of water (Option C): Detection of C. perfringens needs anaerobic incubation and specific media like perfringens agar, not the MPN method, which is for aerobic coliforms.

Determine the total colony count of bacteria in a water sample (Option D): Total bacterial counts are done using the standard plate count method or membrane filtration, not the MPN method, which estimates only coliforms, not total bacteria.

questions.text: Which of the following provides the most reliable evidence of remote faecal contamination of water?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The detection of faecal streptococci and Clostridium perfringens serves as valuable confirmatory evidence of faecal contamination in water, especially in doubtful or borderline cases.

Explanation of other options:

Escherichia coli (Option A): A primary indicator of recent faecal contamination, but it is less resistant and may not be present in long-standing or borderline contamination cases.

Vibrio cholerae (Option B): A specific pathogen responsible for cholera. It does not indicate general faecal pollution and is not used as a confirmatory indicator of contamination.

Pseudomonas aeruginosa (Option D): An environmental bacterium not specifically associated with faecal matter. Its presence does not confirm faecal contamination in water.

choices.text: The well lining should be raised 60-90 cm above ground level to prevent surface contamination.
The well should be located at least 15 meters away from sources of contamination.
The well lining should allow water to enter from the sides to increase water yield.
The well should not be more than 100 meters away from users' houses to ensure regular use.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true regarding the construction of a sanitary well?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In a sanitary well, water should only enter from the bottom, not the sides. The lining must extend to at least 6 meters in depth to ensure this.

Location For Sanitary Well:

  • Must be at least 15 meters (50 feet) away from sources of contamination. (Option B)
  • Should be located on higher ground relative to potential contamination sources (to prevent surface runoff from entering the well).
  • Distance from users' houses is important:
    • Should not be more than 100 meters (100 yards) away, to ensure ease of use and prevent neglect. (Option C)

Lining:

  • Constructed using bricks or stones set in cement.
  • Must extend to a depth of at least 6 meters (20 feet) to allow water to enter from the bottom only, not from the sides.
  • The lining should be raised 60-90 cm (2-3 feet) above ground level to prevent surface contamination. (Option A)

questions.text: Which of the following is not a criterion for water to be considered safe and wholesome?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Chlorine is commonly used for disinfection. Its presence in safe levels is acceptable and often necessary for public health.

Safe and Wholesome Water:

  • Water intended for human consumption should be safe and wholesome, meaning it must be:
    • Free from pathogenic agents (no disease-causing microorganisms). (Option A)
    • Free from harmful chemical substances. (Option B)
    • Pleasant to taste, i.e., no unpleasant colour or odour. (Option D)
    • Usable for domestic purposes (e.g., cooking, cleaning).
  • Polluted/Contaminated Water: Water is considered polluted or contaminated if it does not meet the above criteria.

questions.text: According to WHO guidelines, the permissible amount of residual chlorine allowed in drinking water is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

5 ppm is the WHO guideline for the maximum permissible residual chlorine in drinking water.

Chlorine in Drinking Water:

  • Effective Disinfection Requirements:
    • Free chlorine residual should be ≥ 0.5 mg/L after 30 minutes of contact time at pH < 8.0.
    • A chlorine residual must be maintained throughout the distribution system.
  • Permissible Limits:
    • WHO guideline: up to 5 mg/L (5 ppm) of residual disinfectant.
    • CDC safe limit: up to 4 mg/L (4 ppm). (Option B)
  • These levels are both safe for human consumption and effective for water disinfection.

Explanation of other options:

0.2 ppm (Option A) is the minimum required free chlorine at the point of delivery, not the permissible upper limit.

0.5 ppm (Option C) is the minimum residual free chlorine required after 30 minutes of contact time, not the maximum allowed concentration.

Reference:

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK579453/table/annex3.tab3/

https://www.cdc.gov/drinking-water/about/about-water-disinfection-with-chlorine-and-chloramine.html#
